sentences.text: General elections were held in Rwanda on 15 July 2024 to elect the President of Rwanda|president and members of the Chamber of Deputies (Rwanda)|Chamber of Deputies.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-12 |title=Rwanda to hold presidential, parliamentary polls in July 2024 |url=https://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/tea/news/east-africa/rwanda-to-hold-presidential-parliamentary-polls-in-july-2024-4461852 |access-date=2023-12-15 |website=The EastAfrican |language=en |archive-date=4 February 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240204182004/https://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/tea/news/east-africa/rwanda-to-hold-presidential-parliamentary-polls-in-july-2024-4461852 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Rwanda sets 15 July 2024 election date for presidential, legislative polls |url=https://northafricapost.com/73735-rwanda-sets-15-july-2024-election-date-for-presidential-legislative-polls.html |website=North Africa Post |access-date=2023-12-15 |language=en-US |archive-date=15 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231215094933/https://northafricapost.com/73735-rwanda-sets-15-july-2024-election-date-for-presidential-legislative-polls.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: In an election that was criticised as unfair for its barring of serious opposition candidates, incumbent President Paul Kagame, in office since 2000, was elected to a fourth term (allegedly with over 99% of the vote and a 98.2% turnout) and was inaugurated on 11 August.

references.text: <ref name="Independent-election" /><ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-07-17 |title=Kagame opponents and critics say elections in Rwanda neither free nor fair |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/kagame-opponents-and-critics-say-elections-in-rwanda-neither-free-nor-fair/7702228.html |access-date=2024-07-21 |website=Voice of America |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Rwanda's Kagame sworn in for fourth term after 99 percent election win |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/8/11/rwandas-kagame-sworn-in-for-fourth-term-after-99-percent-election-win |access-date=11 August 2024 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: A 2015 Rwandan constitutional referendum|referendum in 2015 approved constitutional amendments that would allow incumbent President Paul Kagame to run for a third term in office in 2017, as well as shortening presidential terms from seven to five years, although the latter change would not come into effect until 2024. In 2022 Kagame told France 24 that he intended to run for president again in the 2024 election, despite having already served three terms in office.

references.text: <ref name=BBC>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-35049885|title=Paul Kagame's third term: Rwanda referendum on 18 December|website=BBC News|date=9 December 2015|access-date=20 January 2023|archive-date=23 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171123045750/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-35049885|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-62105226 |title=Paul Kagame to seek fourth term as president of Rwanda |date=9 July 2022 |work=BBC News |access-date=5 April 2023 |archive-date=11 January 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240111171116/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-62105226 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Kagame's rule in the country has been described as Authoritarianism|authoritarian. According to Freedom House, Kagame is an autocrat who is responsible for "surveillance, intimidation, torture and Rendition (law)|renditions or suspected assassinations of exiled Dissident|dissidents". Human Rights Watch says that Kagame's government arrested and threatened political opponents. Freedom House considered the elections in Rwanda neither free nor fair, citing reports of ballot stuffing, political intimidation, blocking of opposition challengers, and other undemocratic practices.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Robertson |first=Dylan |date=2023-07-21 |title=Ministers' embrace of Rwanda's Kagame undermines democratic values: governance prof |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/ministers-meet-paul-kagame-1.6914552 |access-date=2024-07-16 |website=CBC |archive-date=16 July 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240716175053/https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/ministers-meet-paul-kagame-1.6914552 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="FreedomHouse-Rwanda">{{cite web |title=Rwanda: Freedom in the World 2024 Country Report |url=https://freedomhouse.org/country/rwanda/freedom-world/2024 |website=Freedom House |access-date=17 July 2024 |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: The president of Rwanda is elected in one round of voting by Plurality (voting)|plurality.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/2160/|title=Rwanda|website=IFES Election Guide|access-date=20 January 2023|archive-date=16 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171116191330/http://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/2160/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text:
* 53 seats directly elected by closed list proportional representation in a single nationwide constituency with an electoral threshold of 5%; seats are allocated using the largest remainder method.
* 27 seats indirectly elected by local and national councils
** 24 Gender quota|reserved for women<ref name="IPU" />
*** Six from the Eastern Province, Rwanda|Eastern, Southern Province, Rwanda|Southern and Western Province, Rwanda|Western provinces
*** Four from Northern Province, Rwanda|Northern Province
*** Two from Kigali
** Two for representatives of youth
** One for representatives of people with disabilities.

references.text: <ref name="IPU">{{cite web|url=http://archive.ipu.org/Parline/reports/2265_B.htm|title=Electoral system|website=Inter-Parliamentary Union|access-date=29 September 2023|archive-date=8 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200208180627/http://archive.ipu.org/Parline/reports/2265_B.htm|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name="aljaz">{{cite web |date=16 September 2013 |title=Rwandans vote in parliamentary elections |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/09/20139169246707534.html |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=29 September 2023 |archive-date=6 September 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200906212531/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/09/20139169246707534.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Around 9.5 million people were registered to vote. Advance voting for overseas Rwandans was held in the country's List of diplomatic missions of Rwanda|diplomatic missions on 14 July. while voting for indirectly elected seats was held on 16 July. Provisional results are expected by 20 July, while the final result is expected on 27 July.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/rwanda-election-president-kagame-d819df3f23e0e0203f7df34d9563a3db |title=Paul Kagame appears set to extend his long presidency of Rwanda in an election Monday |website=Associated Press |date=12 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref name="ajknow"/> Polling on election day opened at 07:00 and lasted until 15:00,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.france24.com/en/africa/20240715-rwanda-heads-to-polls-with-president-kagame-expected-to-secure-fourth-term |title=Rwanda heads to polls with President Kagame expected to secure fourth term |website=France 24 |date=15 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref name="aj">{{Cite web |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/15/rwandas-kagame-eyes-fourth-term-as-voters-head-to-the-polls |title=Rwanda election: Kagame eyes fourth term as voters head to the polls |date=15 July 2024 |access-date=15 July 2024 |website=Al Jazeera |archive-date=15 July 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240715083100/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/15/rwandas-kagame-eyes-fourth-term-as-voters-head-to-the-polls |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/07/12/rwanda-votes-in-elections-president-paul-kagame-is-widely-expected-to-win/ |title=Rwanda votes in elections President Paul Kagame is widely expected to win |website=Africanews |date=12 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Kagame announced his bid for a fourth term on 20 September 2023 in an interview with the pan-African Jeune Afrique magazine, saying "I am happy with the confidence that the Rwandans have shown in me. I will always serve them, as much when I can. Yes, I am indeed a candidate." Kagame's campaign was endorsed by member parties of Rwanda's ruling government coalition, the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF), including the Ideal Democratic Party, the Democratic Union of the Rwandan People, the Prosperity and Solidarity Party, and the Rwandan Socialist Party. Kagame's candidacy was finalised by the RPF without objections at the end of its congress on 9 March 2024. He was also endorsed by the Liberal Party (Rwanda)|Liberal Party and the Social Democratic Party (Rwanda)|Social Democratic Party on 31 March.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/rwandas-veteran-president-kagame-seek-re-election-2024-2023-09-20/ |title=Rwanda's veteran president Kagame to seek re-election in 2024 |date=20 September 2023 |work=Reuters |access-date=29 September 2023 |quote=I am happy with the confidence that the Rwandans have shown in me. I will always serve them, as much when I can. Yes, I am indeed a candidate. |archive-date=25 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231025134307/https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/rwandas-veteran-president-kagame-seek-re-election-2024-2023-09-20/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Frank Habineza of the Democratic Green Party of Rwanda also indicated he would run again in 2024. He had previously run in 2017 Rwandan presidential election|2017.

references.text: <ref name=habineza>{{cite web |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/20/rwanda-kagame-announces-he-will-run-for-a-fourth-term/ |title=Rwanda: Kagame announces he will run for a fourth term |date=20 September 2023 |work=Africanews |access-date=29 September 2023 |quote=The only other candidate so far in the presidential race is lawmaker Frank Habineza of the Green Democratic party. He said he was not surprised by Kagame's announcement and would continue to fight for democracy. |archive-date=11 January 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240111185201/https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/20/rwanda-kagame-announces-he-will-run-for-a-fourth-term/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: In 2019, activist Victoire Ingabire Umuhoza stated that her United Democratic Forces of Rwanda|United Democratic Forces party would challenge Kagame if it was officially recognised by the government. She claimed that there were delays despite her party having the necessary amount of registered members. She said in 2023 that while recognising Kagame's achievements while President, his greatest achievement would be stepping aside to let a peaceful transfer of power take place. However, Ingabire had been convicted in 2010 for threatening state security and downplaying the Rwandan Genocide|Rwandan genocide by asking why no Hutu victims were included in an official memorial.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/africa_rwanda-opposition-figure-presses-against-political-odds/6178473.html |title=Rwanda Opposition Figure Presses On Against Political Odds |last=Elmendorp |first=Ruud |date=30 October 2019 |access-date=27 October 2023 |website=Voice of America |archive-date=5 February 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240205204552/https://www.voanews.com/a/africa_rwanda-opposition-figure-presses-against-political-odds/6178473.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.theelephant.info/op-eds/2023/11/21/why-president-kagame-should-not-run-for-a-fourth-term/ |title=Why President Kagame Should Not Run for a Fourth Term |author=Victoire Ingabire Umuhoza |date=21 November 2023 |access-date=27 November 2023 |website=The Elephant |quote=Therefore, while recognising with gratitude the achievements that he has made over the past three decades, Kagame's greatest achievement yet would be to step away from power at the end of his term in 2024. In so doing, Kagame will have paved the way for better leadership in Rwanda and opened the door to future generations of Rwandans aspiring to become leaders in Rwanda. |archive-date=9 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231209081201/https://www.theelephant.info/op-eds/2023/11/21/why-president-kagame-should-not-run-for-a-fourth-term/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name=":0" /> She was thus barred from running on 13 March 2024.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-68552517 |title=Victoire Ingabire: Rwandan opposition leader barred from election |date=13 March 2024 |access-date=13 March 2024 |website=BBC}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 7 June the Rwandan electoral commission confirmed Paul Kagame, Frank Habineza and Philippe Mpayimana, an independent, as the final candidates for the presidential election, the same three candidates as in 2017. The applications of six other candidates, including Diane Rwigara of the People Salvation Movement, were rejected. The final list of candidates for the presidential and parliamentary election was released on 14 June. The only three presidential candidates allowed to run were the same as from 2017 Rwandan presidential election|2017, where Kagame won with more than 98% of the vote. Deutsche Welle|DW described the election as a "re-run of the non-contest in 2017." ''The Independent'' wrote that the election was "widely criticised as unfair", while Amnesty International criticised the censorship of opposition in the race as having "a chilling effect and limits the space for debate for people of Rwanda".

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cw007n5pn4wo |title=Kagame critic barred from Rwanda's presidential race |date=7 June 2024 |access-date=7 June 2024 |website=BBC}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/06/17/rwanda-two-candidates-up-against-paul-kagame-in-july-15-poll/ |title=Rwanda: Two candidates up against Paul Kagame in July 15 poll |date=18 June 2024 |access-date=18 June 2024 |website=Africanews}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-07-15 |title=Rwanda: President Kagame reelected with 99% — early results |url=https://www.dw.com/en/rwanda-president-kagame-reelected-with-99-early-results/a-69660649 |access-date=2024-07-17 |website=DW |language=en |archive-date=17 July 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240717153512/https://www.dw.com/en/rwanda-president-kagame-reelected-with-99-early-results/a-69660649 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Campaigning was held from 22 June to 12 July.

references.text: <ref name="f24"/> Kagame pledged to continue his policies upon reelection. Habineza criticised censorship and arbitrary detentions under Kagame, and pledged to increase access to water and expand mechanised farming. Mpayimana pledged to reform the mining sector to benefit small-scale miners and expand access to loans for university students, and said that his campaign was also aimed at promoting "political maturity" in the country.<ref name="ajknow">{{Cite web |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/14/will-paul-kagame-win-a-landslide-in-rwanda-election-heres-what-to-know |title=Will Paul Kagame win a landslide in Rwanda election? Here's what to know |date=14 July 2024 |access-date=14 July 2024 |website=Al Jazeera |archive-date=14 July 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240714074525/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/14/will-paul-kagame-win-a-landslide-in-rwanda-election-heres-what-to-know |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 23 June, at an electoral rally attended by Kagame in Rubavu, a crowd crush killed one and injured 37.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/06/25/1-killed-in-stampede-as-rwandas-kagame-begins-campaign-for-reelection/ |title=1 killed in stampede as Rwanda's Kagame begins campaign for reelection |date=25 June 2024 |access-date=25 June 2024 |website=Africanews |archive-date=25 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240625105123/https://www.africanews.com/2024/06/25/1-killed-in-stampede-as-rwandas-kagame-begins-campaign-for-reelection/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Kagame thanked voters over the result in a speech at RPF headquarters in Kigali.

references.text: <ref name="bbcresult">{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cx0247xx585o |title=Kagame wins Rwanda vote in landslide – partial results |date=16 July 2024 |access-date=16 July 2024 |website=BBC}}</ref>
